Eben Oleson.Action: Calls out to Billy about the population sign disappearing for the next thirty days, showing awareness of local tradition but questioning its relevance.
Approaches Beau Brower with a direct question about the gas can, offering help or at least concern for a community member’s issue.
Recognizes that the sign will be unseen for the next thirty days, demonstrating awareness of the situation and environment.
Stops and engages with Beau Brower regarding a mechanical issue, showing initiative and practical engagement.
Issues a citation to Beau for leaking gasoline to protect the town’s roads, explaining that reminders keep Beau connected to the community.
Rips a ticket blithely and tucks it in Beau’s parka with a sarcastic 'Happy motoring.'
Asked Malekai to return the ditch driller before the storm, showing foresight and responsibility.
Did not personally come to help Stella get to the airport despite knowing her situation and the dangerous environment, implied by Stella's sigh and reliance on others.
Malekai mentions Eben wanted the ditch driller back from the airport before the storm hits, implying Eben is managing logistics and planning ahead under time pressure.
Eben is unable to personally run Stella to the airport or prevent the vehicle collision, showing possible limitations in his ability to control or handle unexpected events in town.
Despite the chaos and looming storm, Eben's coordination of equipment like the ditch driller suggests some degree of operational control and responsibility.
No direct intervention or problem-solving from Eben is shown in this excerpt; reliance on others and no visible proactive action are neutral in competence.
Shoos Billy off to let him have a private call, indicating respect for privacy.
Responds warily but lets Stella know he’s there and willing to listen if she wants to talk.
Does not immediately offer to pick up Stella or show urgency, checks watch and covers phone, implying reluctance.
Arranges for Billy to give Stella a ride to the airport rather than going himself, showing practical help but emotional distance.
Immediately responds to Stella’s call, showing awareness and quick decision-making by sending Billy to help her despite the inconvenient timing.
Shoos Billy off to keep the phone call private, indicating situational awareness and control over the interaction.
Checks his watch and remains calm under pressure when coordinating help for Stella, demonstrating time consciousness and emotional composure.
Maintains control of the conversation with Stella, setting conditions for future communication without escalating the situation.
Stops pipeline workers from drinking before sunrise, enforcing rules for safety

Mourns with John Riis and Ally over the death of their dogs, showing shared grief and concern.
Enforces rules at the party by stopping drinking until sunrise but does so without antagonizing others, offering a warning instead of punishment.

Examines the scene carefully, shows concern about ongoing danger

Makes a lighthearted, friendly comment about Carter's wife sending sweaters and the family visiting.

Struggles with vampire instincts, warning his friends away with his eyes to protect them.
Holds off enemies to buy time for Stella and Gail to get inside, prioritizing their safety despite his pain.
His lips pull back in a rictus of pain and feral changes that frighten others.
His voice turns deathly hoarse and he indicates a struggle within, but does not attack friends.
Acknowledges the group's dire situation realistically and communicates it clearly despite his pain.
Refuses to use his inhaler despite struggling to breathe, showing self-control and determination.
Attempts to hold back his vampiric urges and protect his friends, warning them away with his eyes.
Is visibly in agony and undergoing a painful transformation, yet maintains focus on his mission.
Recognizes his limitations in 'You can’t beat them all,' showing awareness of reality but commits to delaying enemies.
Moves deliberately toward danger despite unaccustomed new senses and pain, indicating courage but also risk.
Continues fighting Marlow despite severe injuries, showing resilience and determination.
Repeatedly engages in a brutal hand-to-hand fight with a stronger opponent, maintaining presence of mind to glance at the sky and gauge remaining time.
Is thrown and battered repeatedly, suffers broken bones and a bloody mouth, indicating physical vulnerability in combat.
Though beaten-down, Eben summons strength to headbutt Marlow and regain momentum, demonstrating tactical awareness and fighting skill under pressure.
Sends Billy to take Stella to the airport, anticipating Billy wouldn’t make it, showing foresight and protecting Stella.
Struggles with intense pain and imminent death but focuses on comforting Stella and expressing his feelings clearly.
Despite extreme physical agony and imminent death, maintains emotional clarity and purposeful communication.
